reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of v0.5 (Alpha):
Fallen: A2P Protocol is a turn-based strategy game with RPG elements set in post-apocalyptic world.
If I would to compare it to existing games, I’d say it’s a combination of Fallout with new XCOM.
Even though at the moment the game is in early alpha (not all mechanics are there, the game’s very rough around the edges, some models are missing, textures are low-res, etc), you can pretty much already see what the game will be once it’s done.
If you’d enjoyed a tactical gameplay of XCOM, you’ll probably like the Fallen take on it.
It offers slightly different experience than XCOM because in addition to keeping your team alive, you also have to manage your limited resource - bullets and medkits do not magically refill on missions end here, you’ll actually have to scavenge or trade to get those.
The RPG element comes into play with team management - all of your caravan members have levels, stats (that are raised automatically) and skills (that you have to assign on your own).
Skills are basically the way to specialize your team members into being a melee attacker, ranged assault, medic or some weird mix of all.
Since stats are leveled up automatically (at least in current builds), some characters are going to be more fit for some roles.
The game currently features a couple of pre-made story and side-missions. They have a pretty amusing dialogues, but a lot of things are not quite clear because of the obvious gaps in the storytelling. But that’s something that’ll come later for sure.

Downsides right now:
Since this is alpha, there’s a lot of placeholders and things that are very rough around the edges
A lot of placeholders everywhere
UI is quite dodgy in places at the moment
Quite a lot of times UI does not properly communicates the stats (which is quite important for TBS in my opinion)
A lot of placeholders everywhere - most of the models are same (I wasn’t joking before)
Some of the textures are quite low-res and can be painful to look at in high res

But all of those downsides are very much things in progress and will surely be fixed. If you can put those aside, you’ll find a pretty fun (albeit raw) turn-based strategy experience.
If you think those are a bit too much for you, then wait a bit until beta.

You can watch a bit more in-depth look at the game here:

In this game you command a squad of up to 6 team members in a tactical missions as well as lead a caravan in this post-apocalyptic world on a story mission.
Tactical combat is organized like Fallout: Tactics, every team member have 10 Action Points, they can move, use items, pick up look and fight using this Action Points. Your fighters have some basic stats to start as well as the same leveling path for all of them, there are no classes of fighters as you might expect. Your troopers get familiar with certain weapons as they keep using them and over time this specialty increases to hit chance of that weapon class, therefor you can craft your troopers as you see fit, you can give one a shotgun, good protection clothes and +HP skills and make him an assault while another one will just keep distance with sniper rifle.

I can recommend it for players who like simple tactical combat and don't mind crashes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PMxYScy4mzw

This is a first impression of Fallen A2P Protocol.  The devs, Red Katana, wanted to share early access with me for creating this first impression.  The game is currently in Early Access Alpha so there are many game mechanics still being worked on.  We're discussing the game strictly as a work in progress.  This game is originally fan funded on Kickstarter.

So when you look at this game in action it immediately reminds you of Xcom. So fans of Xcom  and turn based strategy combat should be interested in this game.  It does derive a lot of gameplay elements from Xcom in the combat, but there are many differences as well.   It is not an Xcom clone, it has it's own style of gameplay.

It does take place in the post apocalypse and the game is built around this.  Everything is limited and you are literally scavenging to survive.  In combat you have a limited number of bullets and melee weapons are important.  You have to find or purchase ranged weapons, melee weapons are your backup.  So positioning for attack can vary based on whether you are using melee or ranged weapons.  The attack system is based on AP points and each move you do uses a different amount of AP.  So in order to attack you have to judge how much distance you can move and still fire your attack.  There are also different types of defenses.  There's “hunker down” which reduces the damage you take during the enemy turn.  Then there's “Overwatch” where your character will fire back when the enemy enters your line of sight.  Looting is also crucial.  After each enemy you kill, you'll have to use AP to move to the loot and pick it up.  This is the primary way you get ammo during combat.

When you finish combat, you'll find yourself in the overworld.  You can purchase new items, level up individual characters, and travel to different sites.  The different sites have shops and missions.  Leveling up characters can unlock new passive and active skills and this is done for each character.  So you definitely do not want to lose anyone in combat.  You can also move items around in your inventory.

I'll remind you the game is an Early Access Alpha, but I do see a lot of room for improvement.  The game needs to include basic hotkeys in combat and that to be integrated into the UI.  The overworld UI could use a lot more intuitive functions.  Currently, players have to figure it all out themselves.  The story cut scenes could definitely use more animation and preferably voice overs.

You may want to wait until the final or beta version, but this game is heading in the right direction.  Red Katana is trying to create a solid strategy game.  If you are a huge fan of strategy game and want to support the devs, buy the early access which retails at $15.

reviewText:
Fallen: A2P Protocol:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Your name is Herk West. You and your older brother Silas went to Purgatory to meet Maximus (a worshipper of A2P energy) a so-called old acquaintance of Silas. You were supposed to get an A2P Battery Cell (a new type of energy) for your motorcycle when you realised the incredible betrayal from your brother. He sold you to Maximus and you were thrown unconscious into a pit to be sacrificed to the A2P god!   The sound of gun shots quickly helps you to regain consciousness (yep, that would do the trick almost every time) and to your great surprise, you were rescued by Salvador who kindly hands you a Katana….. Now you have to get out of Purgatory and hunt down your loving brother!

Fallen: A2P Protocol is a tactical turn-based strategy game set in a post-apocalyptic world. At the start of the game, you will have to customize Herk by distributing points between the following attributes; strength, vitality, agility and perception. Then, you will be thrown very quickly into the thick of the story and to your first battle.

When you start a mission, you will command 4 characters but sometimes it might be 3 or 2 depending on how you went in your previous mission and assuming you did not have enough scrap metal (which is your currency) to recruit new characters. It works in a  very similar way to Xcom, Jagged Alliance in terms of gameplay where you will have a specific amount of points allocated to each of your characters for movements or actions per turn. As you go through your missions and eradicate your challenging opponent, make sure you search the fallen enemies and take as much ammunition, weaponry (especially the ones with A2P cells attached to it), armour (hats, boots, vests etc..) and medkits as you can. Oh, sometimes you can find items in cars and boxes scattered in the map.

When you finish your mission, you will be given skill points for each of your characters who are still alive and distribute them on a skills tree. Also, you can upgrade your caravan, but make sure you have enough scrap metal to do so.
Use the travel map to go to different locations where you can recruit new characters, listen to rumours which will lead you to hidden stashes but remember this will cost you a fair bit of scrap metal. However, you will be able to trade items there too. So keep on the lookout for awesome weapons and armours!

In terms of graphics, they could have been slightly more polished in my opinion, but they are sound. I enjoy the dialogues but the voice-over could have been better. On the control side of the equation, they are very easy to learn and I really like the camera view; it works perfectly.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Challenging turn-based strategy game
-	Controls are good and easy to learn
-	Levels are well designed
-	Good gameplay
-	Steam achievements
-	Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Graphics could have been better
-	Voice over could have been better executed

If you are like me and enjoy a good turn-based strategy game, Fallen: A2P Protocol is a game you have to have in your game library.

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having been a fan of squad-based strategy games for many years, I just had to try Fallen: A2P Protocol. This game has promise as a great title, even though it is difficult to visualize the final product in its current state as Early Access. Set in a post-apocalyptic United States, you take command of a rag-tag group of scavengers that stumble upon a mystery of the wasteland. Each member of your squad can equip a variety of ranged and hand-to-hand weaponry, from makeshift swords to rocket launchers. Medikits, grenades, and armor are also available.

The developers helped to sell the post-apocalyptic setting by reducing the availability and limiting your access to weapons, equipment, and ammunition, both through NPC shops and on the battlefield. Granted you can buy and equip your squad with any items from the game at Level 1, assuming the NPC shop has it in its inventory and/or access to early dead body loot. However, ammunition is scarce, and you may only have one shot with that shiny new rocket launcher you have.

In battle, the game tallies and records all actions. Meaning, whenever a good guy or bad guy, shoots, throws an item, or uses a medikit, the game will make sure that item is expended, even after the end of the battle. Those item tallies will affect the items that can be looted from dead bodies. Example: If an enemy sniper has six bullets, and takes three shots by the time your men kill the sniper, looting his body will only get you the three remaining bullets, and his rifle of course.

The battlefield is also affect by weather conditions. Acid rain, extreme heat, and sandstorms are just a few examples. Each weather condition can appear and disappear without warning and will affect the battlefield for a random period of turns. Each weather condition will affect the battlefield in a different way, forcing you to change strategies in the middle of a fight.

There are a few drawbacks to this title that I do feel I need to mention. There a significant lack of roamability, random questing, and the ability to be a murderous vigilante to this post-apocalyptic world. The developers have emphasized (to my general disappointment) that Fallen: A2P Protocol is intended to be quite linear, and there will not be much deviation from the main story missions. Random encounters may be added to this title in the future, but that seems unconfirmed.

Another issue I see with Fallen: A2P Protocol is the lack of character individuality. (I am hoping in the long-term this evaluation is no longer applicable..) Every character you control in the game is a complete copy of the next, in terms of character stats, allowable equipment, and skill tree. (This is Early Access, so I will ignore the copy/paste character models and animations.) There is no variety for being a bunch of random misfits running around the ruins of the United States.

In conclusion, Fallen: A2P Protocol is a Flubber" of a title. There is just enough content to feel interesting and worth peeking at. But it is not developed enough to know where it is going. It is too amorphous and not a lot of shape just yet. I do believe this game can be a great play option
